page.title: 04Cropton Village
page.content: Cropton had a Norman castle which commanded the entrance to Rosedale & later a part-timbered Hall. In the churchyard are the remains of a stone cross from about 1000 AD. The famous whaler & navigator William Scoresby was born here & in the 19th Century one of the Morley family produced a wooden, rocking washing machine now in the Pickering museum. Cropton was once an important centre for limestone quarrying, used both as building material & for burning for lime. Along the wide main street the old stone houses, some of cruck construction, change outwardly only slowly. Most are modernised within. Today, newcomers to the village join the old established families, some still farming. Modern businesses include the post office/ shop, a livestock haulier, riding stables & a satellite systems company.
